sen.j: 道璿（どうせん、702年（長安2年） - 760年5月7日（天平宝字4年4月18日 (旧暦)））は、中国唐代の僧。
sen.e: Dosen (Tao-hsüan in Chinese) (702 - May 7, 760) was a Buddhist monk who lived under the Tang Dynasty in China.
Dosen (702 - May 7, 760) was a Buddhist monk who lived during the Tang Dynasty in China.

sen.j: 洛陽大福先寺に住して定賓（じょうひん）に戒律を、北宗系の禅で第7祖とされる普寂に禅と華厳教学を学んだ。
sen.e: Dosen lived in Daifukusen-ji Temple (Ta-fu-hsien Monastery) of Rakuyo (Luoyang or Loyang in Chinese) so as to have himself enlightened on Vinaya (also called sila, meaning Buddhist precepts) by Johin or Jobin (Dingpin, in Chinese, of the Xiangbu School), and on Chan (Chinese Zen Buddhism) and Huayan (also called Kegon in Japanese, meaning Flower Garland) teachings by Puji (the Venerable Dazhao Chanshi) who was the 7th patriarch in Bodhidharma's line related to the Northern school (Beizong in Chinese and Hokushu in Japanese) of Chan which was founded by Jinshu (Shen-hsiu).
sen.cmt: 定賓は「じょうびん」と読むようです。参考：http://21dzk.l.u-tokyo.ac.jp/INBUDS/search.php?m=trdd&usid=41971&a= 華厳宗http://www.sgilibrary.org/search_dict.php?id=710 普寂 [1] http://books.google.co.jp/books?id=9UUND1nST9kC&pg=PA526&dq=Puji+(Dazhao+Chanshi)&as_brr=0&cd=1#v=onepage&q=Puji%20(Dazhao%20Chanshi)&f=false [2] http://books.google.co.jp/books?id=obdBEXdWwacC&pg=PA45&lpg=PA45&dq=7th+patriarch,+Puji,+Chan&source=bl&ots=2Zdx5k6cGQ&sig=0qZ8sxLwHHm85eK5WxArBYs79_4&hl=ja&ei=JWgUTNasA8yOkQX0yNj2Cw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CBUQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=seventh%20patriarch&f=false 大福先寺http://www.acmuller.net/descriptive_catalogue/indexes/index-monasteries.html

sen.j: 入唐した僧栄叡（ようえい）・普照（ふしょう）の要請により、鑑真に先だち戒律を将来するために日本に招かれ、736年（開元24年、天平8年）インド出身の僧菩提僊那・ベトナム出身の僧仏哲とともに来日する。
sen.e: Japanese monks called Yoei and Fusho who had visited Tang invited Dosen to Japan so as to have him bring Vinaya (also called sila or precepts) to Japan prior to Ganjin (Jiàn zhēn in Chinese), and Dosen thus came to Japan in 736 (equivalent of Kaigen 24 in Tang China, Tenpyo 8 in Japan), accompanied by Bodaisenna (Bodhisena) from India and Buttetsu from Chăm Pa (present-day Vietnam).
sen.cmt: 原文に「栄叡（えいよう）」とありましたが、読みは（ようえい）ですので、修正の上訳出しました。仏哲は仏徹とも書くようです。
sen.e: Japanese monks called Yoei and Fusho, who had visited Tang, invited Dosen to Japan so as to have him bring Vinaya to Japan prior to Ganjin, and Dosen thus came to Japan in 736 (equivalent of Kaigen 24 in Tang China, Tenpyo 8 in Japan), accompanied by Bodaisenna (Bodhisena) from India and Buttetsu from Vietnam.

sen.j: 渡来後の道璿は、北宗禅を広めるため、大安寺に「禅院」を設置し、戒律では『梵網経疏』を撰した。
sen.e: Dosen in Japan attempted to spread the teachings of the Northern school of Chan (Zen) by building a 'Zen-in' Temple at Daian-ji Temple and edited "Bonmokyo-sho" (Exegesis on Fanwan Jing [Bonmokyo]) for teaching the Vinaya precepts.

sen.j: 後に、吉野の比蘇山寺に入り、修禅に精励し、山岳修験者にも少なからぬ影響を与えたとされる。
sen.e: After the Daian-ji Temple, Dosen entered Hisosan-ji Temple in Yoshino, where he applied himself to Zen training, thereby supposedly influencing Sangaku-shugenja (mountaineering ascetics) a great deal.

sen.j: 最澄の「四種相承」（天台・密教・禅宗・大乗戒）の思想は、道璿が伝えた玉泉天台（荊州玉泉寺の天台）の影響とされる。
sen.e: Saicho (Dengyo Daishi)'s idea of "Shishu Sosho" (literally, four types of inheritance of Buddhism: Tendai [Tiantai], Shingon [true word or Sino-Japanese esoteric Buddhism], Zen [Chan], and Kai [Vinaya, sila or precept] of Mahayana Buddhism) was allegedly influenced by the teachings of Gyokusen (literally, gem spring) Tendai (the Tiantai group at the Yuquansi [Gyokusen-ji Temple] in Jingzhou, present-day Hubei and Hunan Provinces of China) that Dosen had introduced.
